poem:
### A Parade in Moscow

Ashes of memory  
drift,  
uninvited,  
across borders—  
shadows  
cast in procession.

Steel whispers  
echo off cobblestones,  
and the air, thick  
with ceremony  
and silence,  
holds its breath—  
shame lingering  
like smoke  
in the aftermath  
of applause.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "European leaders attending Russia parade ‘bring shame’ on themselves, Tusk says – as it happened 5.55pm BST Closing summary Polish prime minister Donald Tusk said that anyone attending the military parade in Moscow to mark the end of the second world war had brought shame on themselves, after Slovak prime minister Robert Fico became the only European Union leader to attend. The United States and its European allies are finalising a proposal for a 30-day". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
